lexUnit.name: rattle.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to feel nervous, worried, or irritated.

sentence.text: The Dean had rattled me so much in the morning that I decided to look up a few precedents . "
A detailed inventory of Bruce 's day followed , and McLeish understood that having Catherine Crane working on this case had rattled Bruce in several ways .
It is interesting for the accounts of the skirmishing that rattled Canada in its early years , and the actions between Canada and the nascent USA .
The sarcasm bit deep and rattled her .
You think I 'm stupid to let her rattle me . "
` Then on the Saturday , something rattles you .
If you can just keep your cool , he ca n't rattle you . "

The Socialists are so rattled by the prospect of losing at least three of the seven Cadiz parliamentary seats to Mr Pacheco that they coaxed Dona Carmen into leaving the Moncloa palace and joining the fray .
I am continually rattled by his insecurity .
Banbridge started the second half in more determined mood and forced Bangor back and the home side were rattled by some excellent play by the visitors .
But last night Mr Milburn said : ` The Tories are clearly rattled by this new campaign .
Only once Hilary admits to being seriously rattled .
Alexander was rattled , disturbed in his habits , by instant fame , by being treated as a major dramatist .
It fell with a crash which rattled her composure and set her heart thudding .
If Spunk had been hoping to rattle me by picking this place for a venue , then Spunk was out of luck .
